answers: Nazism [or National Socialism; or Nazi party]
parts: Name this poet who declares, “I shall never get you put together entirely” in “The Colossus.”

This poem by Plath describes attempting suicide with the opening line “I have done it again. / One year in every ten / I manage it--” The title character of this poem rises “out of the ash” and eats men “like air.”

In Sylvia Plath’s poem “Daddy,” she frequently references this specific ideology, with lines like “Every woman adores a Fascist,” describing the title character as “Not God but a swastika” and as “A man in black with a Meinkampf look.”
Name this World War II battle, which took place in Egypt. This battle saw Erwin Rommel’s forces defeated by the Desert Rats.
This British general led the Desert Rats and was victorious at El Alamein.
Montgomery was defeated at the Battle of Arnhem, which was part of Operation Market Garden, an Allied attempt to cross this river.

answers: sola fide [or salvation by grace alone; or salvation by faith alone]
parts: Name this doctrine which states that salvation is not possible only through good works, but rather requires an act of belief in God on the part of the individual.
Sola fide [“sole-a feed-ay”] was the rallying cry of this general denomination, whose namesake “Reformation” included leaders like John Calvin. It was opposed by the Council of Trent.
Martin Luther and John Calvin espoused “single” and “double” versions, respectively, of this doctrine concerning the fate of the dead. This idea can be considered a religious form of determinism.

answers: Stephen A. Smith [or Stephen Anthony Smith]
parts: Name this Boston Celtics small forward, whose record of 10 games of 20 or more points in their first playoffs is only matched by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.

Tatum and this other player are the only two to drop 20 points in three consecutive playoff games. This longtime Lakers shooting guard finished with 60 points in his last game before retiring in 2016.
This vocal SportsCenter analyst and co-host on First Take with Max Kellerman and Molly Qerim supported the hype around Tatum.

answers: calorimetry [or differential scanning calorimetry; or word forms, such as using a calorimeter]
parts: Name this physical property that specifies the transition temperature between a substance’s solid and liquid phases.

The melting point of a substance can be determined by performing the “differential scanning” type of this technique. This technique, used to measure heat changes, can also be performed using coffee cups.
These types of calorimeters are constant-volume devices used to measure the heat exchanged during combustion reactions. They are named for being able to withstand large pressures.

answers: Aksum [or Axum, or the Aksumite Empire]
Ethiopia [or ītiyop’iya; or Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia; or YeEtiyop’iya]
Italy [or Italia; or Italian Republic; or Repubblica Italiana]
parts: Name this trading empire in the Horn of Africa. Along with Alodia and Makuria, it was one of the first Christian kingdoms in the region, and its capital still allegedly holds the Ark of the Covenant.
The northern part of this modern-day country was ruled by the Kingdom of Axum. This country’s emperors included Menelik II and Haile Selassie, the Rastafarian Messiah.
During its second invasion of Ethiopia, this country used poison gas on Haile Selassie’s defenders. This country was defeated in its first invasion of Ethiopia at Adowa by Menelik II.

Name these unpitched percussion instruments. Onstage and offstage versions of these “herdenglocken” are to invoke a pastoral feel as the “last earthly sounds” are heard “by the departing spirit on the mountain top.”
In Mahler’s 6th, these large, bowl-shaped tunable drums play an underpinning dotted rhythm to the “fate” motif in the 1st movement march, and open the scherzo with a short solo.

Three “blows of fate” from this other unusual instrument are called for in Mahler’s 6th symphony, but usually only two are played. This instrument is described as “powerful, but dull in resonance, with a non-metallic character.”
Name these extremely small, uncharged particles with electron, muon and tau flavors.

This neutrino observatory near Hida, Japan, uses a huge underground vat of very pure water to detect neutrinos. This observatory was the first instrument to detect neutrinos created by a supernova in 1987.
Photomultiplier tubes around Super-K’s tank detect light from Cherenkov [“chair-en-kov”] radiation, which glows this color. The color charges on quarks can be red, green, or this color.
Name this author, who described “purblind doomsters” in “Hap” and seeing a bird who knew “some blessed hope” in “The Darkling Thrush.”
Thomas Hardy’s poem “The Convergence of the Twain” is about this “unsinkable ship,” who meets her end with “a sinister mate,” “A Shape of Ice.”
This novel by Thomas Hardy takes its title from a line in “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard.” This novel focuses on the life and relationships of Bathsheba Everdene.

Name this super-intelligent computer that attempts to thwart Dave Bowman’s mission to Jupiter to investigate a mysterious radio signal. In one scene, Bowman begs this character to “open the pod bay doors.”
HAL-9000 is the antagonist of this Stanley Kubrick film based on an Arthur C. Clarke story, in which a monolith of unknown origin appears at different points in human evolution.
A shot in 2001: A Space Odyssey is a match-cut juxtaposing a bone thrown in the air with one of these vehicles. Other examples of these vehicles include the USS Enterprise and the Millennium Falcon.
Name this English philosopher, who presented five principles of inductive reasoning in his A System of Logic. He also wrote The Subjection of Women with his wife, Harriet Taylor

Mill was a proponent of this school of philosophy founded by Jeremy Bentham. This school of ethics argues for a moral calculus to find the method that produces the greatest good for the greatest number of people.
In On Liberty, Mill distinguishes between this action and mere offense. He argues that the only reason for government to reduce a person’s liberty is to prevent this from happening to other people.

answers: Cuba [or Republic of Cuba; or Republica de Cuba]
Turkey [or Republic of Turkey; or Turkiye Cumhuriyeti]
parts: Name this ultimately failed invasion, which saw the defeat of Brigade 2506.
The Bay of Pigs Invasion sought to overthrow this country’s Communist government, led at the time by Fidel Castro.
The failed Bay of Pigs invasion partially led to the Cuban Missile Crisis, which was also partially a response to the US harboring missiles in Italy and this other European country.
Name these solids, which are convex polyhedra with faces composed of congruent convex regular polygons. There are five of these solids in three dimensions.
The regular 3D form of this shape is a Platonic solid with all sides made of pentagons. Kepler’s interest in pomegranate seeds led him to discover the “rhombic” form of this shape.
Kepler also conjectured that either cubic or hexagonal close packing of these shapes is the densest possible. The volume of these shapes is equal to four-thirds pi r cubed.
Name this non-Shelley poet, who wondered in another poem if the title bird pursues its “solitary way.”
In this Bryant poem known as a “meditation on death,” he instructs the reader to “approach thy grave, / Like one who wraps the drapery of his couch / About him and lies down to pleasant dreams.”
William Cullen Bryant was a long-time editor of this city’s Evening Post. Other newspapers in this city include Bloomsbury and its namesake Times.

answers: slaves [or Dying Slave; or Rebellious Slave]
Michelangelo [or Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni]
parts: Name this type of person. Sculptures of Dying and Rebellious versions of these type of people were originally created for the tomb of Pope Julius II.
The most famous feature of Julius II’s tomb is a sculpture of this biblical man with horns, due to the Latin Vulgate’s translation of Exodus.
This Renaissance artist was commissioned by Pope Julius II for his tomb and to paint scenes such as The Last Judgement in the Sistine Chapel.

answers: Apep [or Apepi or Aapep or Apophis]
Set [or Seth or Setesh or Sutekh or Setekh or Suty]
Khepri [or Khepera; or Kheper; or Khepra; or Chepri]
parts: This god of chaos, who is represented as a serpent, attacks Ra’s barge during its nightly journey through the Duat.
Along with the goddess Sekhmet, this god of deserts and storms assists Ra in his nightly battle against Apep, though he is more well known for murdering Osiris.
At the end of the journey, Ra is reborn in the form of this scarab beetle, the embodiment of the rising sun.
Pinnacles National Park is located in this state. This state is also the site of Joshua Tree and Kings Canyon National Parks.
This other park in California contains Badwater Basin, at 282 feet below sea level, and Furnace Creek, the site of the world’s highest recorded temperature at 134 degrees Fahrenheit.

This national park, which includes Santa Cruz Island in its namesake archipelago [“ar-kuh-pell-ah-go”], extends along the coast from Santa Barbara to Los Angeles. A European archipelago with the same name contains Guernsey and Jersey.
Name this structure which impedes influx of most compounds into parts of the nervous system from the circulatory system. This structure prevents diffusion via endothelial tight junction complexes.
These cells help maintain the blood-brain barrier by forming the glia limitans, endfeet protrusions that ensheath the capillaries. These glial cells are named for their star-like appearance.
After one of these events where blood flow to the brain is cut off, astrocytes can become reactive, forming a glial scar. These events often cause weakness in one side of the body.

answers: Chinua Achebe [“ah-chay-bay”] [or Albert Chinua Achebe; or Albert Chinualumogu Achebe]
parts: Name this author who criticized Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness for its racist portrayal of African people in “An Image of Africa.”

This Chinua Achebe novel follows the life of Okonkwo, whose village of Umuofia [“u-mow-fee-ah”]  is brought under the influence of British colonialism and Christian missionaries. This novel’s title refers to the crumbling of Igbo culture.
These elders are the judges of the Umuofia village. Enoch rips off the masks of one of these representations of ancestral spirits, resulting in this band burning down Enoch’s compound.

answers: famine [or Irish Potato Famine; or Great Famine]
Winston Churchill [or Sir Winston Leonard Spencer-Churchill]
parts: Name these mass food shortages. Irish people used coffin ships to flee one of these events caused by a potato blight.
Joseph Stalin was largely responsible for the Holodomor, a famine that killed over seven million people in this modern-day country.
This British Prime Minister was criticized by Madhusree Mukerjee in her book [This Man’s] Secret War for refusing to send aid during India’s Bengal Famine. This man coined the term “iron curtain.”
